Jeb Hensarling [chairman of the committee] presiding.</hearing-info> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Jeb Hensarling stating that the Democrats"> Members present: Representatives Hensarling, Royce, Pearce, Posey, Luetkemeyer, Huizenga, Duffy, Stivers, Hultgren, Ross, Pittenger, Wagner, Barr, Rothfus, Messer, Tipton, Williams, Poliquin, Love, Hill, Emmer, Zeldin, Trott, Loudermilk, MacArthur, Davidson, Budd, Kustoff, Tenney, Hollingsworth; Waters, Maloney, Velazquez, Sherman, Meeks, Capuano, Clay, Lynch, Scott, Green, Cleaver, Moore, Ellison, Perlmutter, Foster, Kildee, Delaney, Sinema, Beatty, Heck, Vargas, Gottheimer, Gonzalez, Crist, and Kihuen. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Financial Services Committee will come to order. Without objection, the Chair is authorized to declare a recess of the committee at any time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Today's hearing is entitled, ``A Legislative Proposal to Create Hope and Opportunity for Investors, Consumers, and Entrepreneurs.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">I now recognize myself for 5 minutes to give an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">It has been almost 7 years since the passage of the Dodd- Frank Act. We were told it would lift our economy, but instead we are stuck in the slowest, weakest, most tepid recovery in the history of the republic.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The economy does not work for working people. They have seen their paychecks stagnate; they have seen their savings decimated. We have seen millions who remain unemployed and underemployed in an economy working at roughly half of its potential.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Dodd-Frank has been a bigger burden to enterprise than all other Obama-era regulations combined. There is a better way, and it is the Financial CHOICE Act of 2017.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">This bill replaces onerous government fiat with market discipline, ends bailouts with bankruptcy, throws a deregulatory life preserver to our community financial institutions, replaces complexity with simplicity, holds both Washington and Wall Street accountable, and unleashes capital formation so the economy can move yet again for the betterment of all of our citizens.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Under the Financial CHOICE Act there will be economic opportunity for all and bank bailouts for none--again, bank bailouts for none. Perhaps that is why press reports indicate that most Wall Street banks oppose the Financial CHOICE Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The damage Dodd-Frank has done to consumers and business is well known to every Member, but let me remind you of just a few: 75 percent of banks used to offer free checking before Dodd-Frank became law; by 2016 only 38 percent did. Minimum balance requirements to qualify for free checking have almost quadrupled, and average monthly fees more than tripled. This helps explain why the number of households that are unbanked and underbanked is up by more than 3 million since the passage of Dodd-Frank.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Data show that there are 50 million fewer credit cards available since 2008 and the remaining options cost more now, hurting small businesses and struggling families. The Federal Reserve reports that once Dodd-Frank's qualified mortgage rule is fully phased in, an estimated one-third of Black and Hispanic borrowers will be denied mortgages due to its rigid debt-to-income ratio.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">An overwhelming majority of community banks report that Dodd-Frank's regulatory burdens are preventing them from making more residential mortgage loans. And they have had to hire more staff just to deal with the legal compliance issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Dodd-Frank Act represents an even more dangerous prospect, namely, politicized lending. Washington elites are now allocating our capital to fulfill their agendas, devoid of any checks and balances or due process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">And it is impossible to bring up the threat of politicized lending without bringing up the CFPB. The Financial CHOICE Act reestablishes this rogue agency as a civil enforcement agency patterned after the Federal Trade Commission, one that is responsible for actually enforcing the enumerated consumer protection laws written by Congress instead of making up its own law in an unfair, deceptive, and abusive manner.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">True consumer protection is only to be had in competitive, transparent, and innovative markets which are vigorously policed for fraud and deception. That is what the Financial CHOICE Act is all about.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The bill releases financial institutions from regulations that create more burden than benefit in exchange for meeting high, yet simple capital requirements--that is, loss-absorbing capital, which is like an insurance policy against failure.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Instead of government bureaucrats overseeing banks that plan their failures, the CHOICE Act will see banks plan for their expansions by helping grow the economy for every citizen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The Financial CHOICE Act repeals Washington's authority to designate too-big-to-fail firms--or SIFIs, as they are known going forward, and retroactively repeals previous nonbank SIFI designations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The bill recognizes that illegal activity by bad actors at financial institutions can harm the financial well-being of consumers and society and, therefore, imposes the toughest penalty in history for financial fraud, self-dealing, and deception.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The bill repeals the misguided, complex, and unneeded Volcker Rule, as it has made capital markets less liquid, more fragile, and threatens financial stability. Even a Federal Reserve report now admits to this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The bill would unleash opportunities for economic growth, foster capital formation, and provide Main Street job creators with regulatory relief so more Americans can go back to work at good careers and give their families a better life.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Ending the bureaucratic nightmare that is Dodd-Frank and replacing it with the simpler capital rules of the Financial CHOICE Act is imperative. America has struggled for far too long.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">It is time again to hold Washington accountable; it is time to hold Wall Street accountable. It is time for economic growth for all; it is time for bank bailouts for none.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">So I look forward today to our hearing, and to soon passing the Financial CHOICE Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> I now recognize the ranking member for 4 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Waters</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Ms. Waters">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Ms. Waters">And thank you, to the witnesses, for being here today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Ms. Waters">There is only one explanation for why we are here discussing yet another dead-on-arrival version of the wrong choice act. It must be that the foreclosure crisis and the Great Recession somehow weren't enough for the Majority, and so they irrationally want to clear the way for round two.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Ms. Waters">I want to be very clear for anyone who is watching: That is exactly what this bill would result in.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Ms. Waters">The wrong choice act thoroughly dismantles Wall Street reform, guts the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and takes us back to the system that allowed risky and predatory Wall Street practices and products to crash our economy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Ms. Waters">During the Great Recession, because of the actions of reckless financial institutions, Americans lost $13 trillion in household wealth, 11 million Americans lost their homes, and the unemployment rate climbed to 10 percent. The impact was widespread and harmful to all.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Ms. Waters">The wrong choice act paves the path back to that kind of economic ruin by rolling back the critical safeguards we put in place in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act to protect American consumers, investors, and the economy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Ms. Waters">Today we have sensible Dodd-Frank rules and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to prevent financial institutions from peddling toxic products or abusing hardworking American consumers. Since its creation the CFPB has returned nearly $12 billion to more than 29 million consumers who have been ripped off by financial institutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Ms. Waters">With this financial cop on the block and with important rules of the road in place, Wall Street reform has worked. Since Dodd-Frank passage the economy has created 16 million jobs over 85 consecutive months, and business lending has increased 75 percent. Banks large and small are posting all- time record profits; community banks are out-performing larger banks; and credit unions are expanding their membership.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Ms. Waters">But here we are. And even though Wall Street reform has made them safer and they are raking in profits, that is not enough for the banks. They want to go back to the bad old days of fewer protections, and they have shamelessly undertaken a full-court press to get a long wish list of giveaways, most of which have been compiled in this bill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Ms. Waters">Democrats are going to fight against it and stand up for Main Street. This bill must not become law. There is too much at stake for consumers and for our whole economy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Ms. Waters"> And I will now yield to Mr. Kildee, the vice ranking member. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Kildee</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Kildee">Thank you, Madam Ranking Member, for yielding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Kildee">This so-called Financial CHOICE Act ends the most important aspects of Wall Street reform, which were designed and passed to prevent another financial crisis. Pushing this bill puts Wall Street ahead of Main Street once again.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Kildee">The wrong choice for hardworking Americans, it puts Wall Street back in charge and does away with those very protections that were enacted after the financial crisis, and puts the economy back at risk.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Kildee">And let me be clear: I and other Members on this side support improving some aspects of Dodd-Frank.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Kildee">But have we forgotten the lessons of the financial crisis? This takes us back to the days where Wall Street practices nearly crippled our economy, back to the days where millions of people lost their homes, lost their jobs, saw their retirement savings wiped out. The people that I represent have not forgotten these dark days, and the committee should not forget them either.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Kildee">Removing these important financial safeguards while at the same time eliminating the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, designed to protect consumers against those abuses, is the wrong choice and this committee ought to reject that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Kildee"> With that, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Hensarling"> The Chair now yields 1 minute to the gentleman from California. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Mr. Chairman, this CHOICE Act takes some good bills that passed this committee with overwhelming and bipartisan majorities, puts them together with a lot more bad bills that do not have bipartisan support, and gives Members no choice. They are ultimately going to have to vote up or down.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Mr. Chairman, please break up this bill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Sherman">You say we don't have free checking anymore. You used to pay for checking because your checking account got about 4 percent less interest than the passbook account. In a zero interest rate environment or even a very low interest rate environment, obviously banks got rid of free checking in many cases, and in other cases they are trying to get it unfreezed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Finally, you say we don't have the economy we need. We need a better trade policy. You can't have a half-trillion-dollar trade deficit and then say, ``We are going to make up for that by deregulating the banks and reinstituting the disasters that we suffered in 2008.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Sherman">The idea that we can make up for bad trade policies and restore the economy by letting Wall Street do anything they want didn't work in 2008. It is not going to work now.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Hensarling</speaker> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">The gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">We will now turn to our panel of witnesses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">First, we welcome the testimony of Mr. Peter Wallison. He is the Arthur F. Burns fellow in financial policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute. He previously served as General Counsel of the U.S. Treasury Department and as White House Counsel to President Reagan. He received both his B.A. and J.D. from Harvard University.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Second, Dr. Norbert Michel is a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation. He was previously a professor at Nicholls State University College of Business, where he taught finance, economics, and statistics. Dr. Michel holds his B.A. from Loyola University and a doctoral degree in financial economics from the University of New Orleans.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Third, the Honorable Michael Barr is a professor of law at the University of Michigan Law School, where he teaches financial regulation, international finance, and financial derivatives. He previously served as Assistant Secretary for Financial Institutions at the Treasury Department. He received both his B.A. and J.D. from Yale University.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Fourth, Mr. Alex Pollock is the distinguished senior fellow at the R Street Institute. Previously he served as a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, and as the president and CEO of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago. He received his B.A. from Williams College, a Master's in Philosophy from the University of Chicago, and a Master's of Public Administration from Princeton University.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Fifth, Dr. Lisa Cook is an associate professor of economics and international relations at Michigan State University. Previously, she was a senior economist on the Council of Economic Advisors. As a Marshall scholar she received her B.A. from Spelman College and a second B.A. from Oxford University; she earned a Ph.D. in economics from the University of California Berkeley.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Sixth, Ms. Hester Peirce is a senior research fellow at the Mercatus Center. She previously served as staff for the Senate Banking Committee, as well as the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ms. Peirce earned her B.A. in economics from Case Western Reserve University and her J.D. from Yale Law School.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">And last but not least, Mr. John Allison is the former president and chief executive officer of the Cato Institute. Prior to his time at Cato he was the longstanding chairman and CEO of BB&T Bank. Mr. Allison graduated from the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill and received his Master's Degree in management from Duke University.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Each of you will be recognized for 5 minutes to give an oral presentation of your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">I think perhaps with one exception, you have all testified here before, but as a slight refresher course, green means go, yellow means you have 1 minute left, and red means you had best wrap it up.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Chairman Hensarling">Without objection, each of your written statements will be made a part of the record.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF PETER J. WALLISON, ARTHUR F. BURNS FELLOW,</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="PETER J. WALLISON">Mr. Wallison, you are now recognized for 5 minutes for your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="PETER J. WALLISON"> FINANCIAL POLICY STUDIES, AMERICAN ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Wallison</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Wallison">Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member Waters, and members of the committee. Thanks for the opportunity to comment on the Financial CHOICE Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Wallison">The act would repeal or substantially modify large portions of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act. As outlined in my prepared testimony, there are two important things to know about Dodd- Frank: It is primarily responsible for the historically slow recovery of the U.S. economy since the 2008 financial crisis; and it was completely unnecessary.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Wallison">Enacted hurriedly, Dodd-Frank misdiagnosed the financial crisis. Without serious investigation, the Obama Administration and Congress assumed or wanted to believe that the crisis was caused by insufficient regulation of Wall Street and the financial system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Wallison">In 2009, before any committee hearings, Chairman Barney Frank said that Congress would adopt a ``New New Deal.'' He was correct. The Dodd-Frank Act was by far the most restrictive financial regulatory law since the 1930s.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Wallison">If, instead of jumping to pass new regulations, Congress had stopped to consider why we had a financial crisis it would have found government housing policies were the cause. MICHEL"> FINANCIAL REGULATIONS AND MONETARY POLICY, THE HERITAGE </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Michel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Michel">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Michel">Chairman Hensarling, Ranking Member Waters, members of the committee, thank you for the opportunity to testify today.
